Problem:
Assume that we have a system modeled by the equation \\( z(t + 1) = Mz(t) \\), where M is a linear operator represented by a matrix. We consider the modification caused by a transformation \\( h(z) = N^t z \\), where N is also a matrix representation of a linear operator.

If \\( h(z) \\) is applied to an initial state \\( z_0 \\) and allowed to evolve under the original model \\( z(t + 1) = Mz(t) \\) without further intervention, will \\( z(t) \\) at t = T equal the state obtained by evolving \\( z_0 \\) under the model for T steps without transformation?
Explanation: Applying \\( h(z) \\) to the initial state modifies it by \\( N^t z_0 \\), which changes the trajectory of the system. The resultant state at any future time point, including t = T, will differ unless N and M commute, which is not generally the case.
